metadata.title: Acute kidney injury in patients hospitalized with COVID-19 in Wuhan, China: A single-center retrospective observational study MDRD Modification of Diet in Renal Disease CT Computed tomography PCR Polymerase chain reaction ACE2 Angiotensin converting enzyme II SARS-CoV Serve acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus WHO World Healthy Organization

abstract.original_text: evaluated the association between changes in the incidence of AKI and COVID-19 disease and clinical outcomes by using logistic regression models.

sentences.segment_text: evaluated the association between changes in the incidence of AKI and COVID-19 disease and clinical outcomes by using logistic regression models .

abstract.original_text: Results: A total of 287 patients, 55 with AKI and 232 without AKI, were included in the analysis.

sentences.segment_text: Results : A total of 287 patients ,
55 with AKI and 232 without AKI ,
were included in the analysis .

abstract.original_text: Compared to patients without AKI, AKI patients were older, predominantly male, and were more likely to present with hypoxia and have pre-existing hypertension and cerebrovascular disease. Moreover, AKI patients had higher levels of white blood cells, D-dimer, aspartate aminotransferase, total bilirubin, creatine kinase, lactate dehydrogenase, procalcitonin, C-reactive protein, a higher prevalence of hyperkalemia, lower lymphocyte counts, and higher chest computed tomographic scores. The incidence of stage 1 AKI was 14.3%, and the incidence of stage 2 or 3 AKI was 4.9%. Patients with AKI had substantially higher mortality.

sentences.segment_text: Compared to patients without AKI ,
AKI patients were older , predominantly male ,
and were more likely to present with hypoxia and have pre-existing hypertension and cerebrovascular disease .
Moreover , AKI patients had higher levels of white blood cells ,
D-dimer , aspartate aminotransferase , total bilirubin ,
creatine kinase , lactate dehydrogenase ,
procalcitonin , C-reactive protein , a higher prevalence of hyperkalemia ,
lower lymphocyte counts , and higher chest computed tomographic scores .
The incidence of stage 1 AKI was 14.3 % ,
and the incidence of stage 2 or 3 AKI was 4.9 % .
Patients with AKI had substantially higher mortality .

abstract.original_text: Conclusions: AKI is an important complication of COVID-19. Older age, male, multiple pre-existing comorbidities, lymphopenia, increased infection indicators, elevated D-dimer, and impaired heart and liver functions were the risk factors of AKI. AKI patients who progressed to stages 2 or 3 AKI had a higher mortality rate.

sentences.segment_text: Conclusions : AKI is an important complication of COVID-19 .
Older age , male , multiple pre-existing comorbidities ,
lymphopenia , increased infection indicators ,
elevated D-dimer , and impaired heart and liver functions were the risk factors of AKI .
AKI patients who progressed to stages 2 or 3 AKI had a higher mortality rate .
